bioghist.p: Nelson Fuson (1913-2006) was born in Guangzhou, China, to American Presbyterian missionaries, Chester and Phebe Fuson. Fuson earned his master's in physics and astronomy at Kansas University in 1935 and his Ph.D. in physics at the University of Michigan in 1938. He then worked as an instructor in physics at Rutgers University, New Brunswick, New Jersey. Beginning in 1941, as the U.S. became involved in World War II, Fuson served as a conscientious objector in Civilian Public Service (CPS) workcamps at Patapsco, Maryland, Goshen, Indiana, Big Flats, New York, and Trenton, North Dakota. He also attended the experimental Columbia University Training Unit in International Administration, and worked for several months at Pendle Hill, Pennsylvania, directing a CPS China Relief unit (which was blocked by a congressional military appropriations bill rider), and a final year in CPS "detached service" doing infrared research on penicillin at the University of Michigan. After the war, Fuson participated in several international service seminars sponsored by the American Friends Service Committee (AFSC).

scopecontent.p: This collection consists of the papers of Nelson Fuson, primarily from the period when he served in the Civilian Public Service (1941 to 1945) and the period following World War II. Materials include: correspondence, reports, newsletters, schedules, meeting minutes, and photographs from various CPS workcamps; correspondence, newsletters, and course work from the Columbia University Training Unit in International Administration; correspondence and memos from the 1943 Chicago Conference on Social Action; addresses, memos, and other writings by Fuson; and programs, reports, correspondence, and photographs from AFSC International Service Seminars from 1946 to 1949. The collection also includes letters to friends from Marian and Nelson Fuson during their sabbatical in France (1956-1959); letters from Nelson Fuson to Marian before and just after their marriage; and a small batch of correspondence with Kate and Eberhard Tacke, a couple the Fusons met during their stay in Europe; etchings and a drawing by Eberhard Tacke; and several civil rights-era phonograph albums and an AFSC anniversary recording.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
